awd_titl_txt: SHF: CSR: Small: Integrated Design and Verification of High-Confidence Interactive Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
High-confidence computer systems are those that require a high level of assurance of correct operation.
Many of these systems are interactive - they interact with a human being - and the human operator's role is central to the operation of the system. Examples of such systems include fly-by-wire aircraft control systems (interacting with a pilot), drive-by-wire automobile systems (interacting with a driver), medical devices (interacting with a doctor), and electronic voting machines (interacting with a voter). The costs of incorrect operation in all such systems can be very severe. It is essential to develop techniques to ensure correct operation of such systems. However, this is very challenging due in part to the difficulty of formally specifying all parts of an interactive system.

This project is developing an approach for the principled design of high-confidence interactive systems where correctness is certified through a combination of formal verification and testing by humans. The approach has three components. First, systems are designed according to a set of guiding principles that ease verification and testing, including determinism, independence, and unambiguity. Second, new algorithmic techniques are being developed to perform formal verification of the above determinism, independence, and unambiguity properties on system designs. Finally, the above design principles and formal verification are leveraged to test the human-computer interface with a tractable number of tests. The approach is applicable to a range of high-confidence interactive systems, including avionics, medical devices, and electronic voting systems.

Human/operator error is one of the major sources of failures in high-confidence systems, and this project seeks to reduce the occurrence of such failures through a tight integration of principled design, formal verification, and systematic testing. The approach is being integrated into the curriculum and projects in undergraduate and graduate courses at UC Berkeley.

por.por_cntn:
Society is increasingly reliant on computational systems that interact closely with humans. Examples include automobiles with self-driving features that interact with drivers, pedestrians, and other human-driven vehicles, and advanced computer-controlled medical and surgical devices that interact with doctors, nurses, and patients. Since such systems operate in safety-critical and mission-critical settings, their safe and correct operation is extremely important. The objective of this project was to develop an approach for the principled design of high-confidence interactive systems where correctness is certified through a combination of formal verification and testing by humans. To this end, the project included the following major accomplishments: 

(i) Intellectual Merit: On the theoretical side, a new formal framework was developed for the modeling, design, and analysis of human-in-the-loop control systems. This framework identified the notion of an advisory controller as a component that obtains inputs from the autonomous and human controllers and decides how to share control between them. Additionally, the framework identifies four key requirements of human-in-the-loop controllers. Apart from this framework, the project developed novel techniques for synthesizing human-in-the-loop controllers that include the logic for both the autonomous controller and the advisory controller so that the synthesized controllers are correct by construction (see attached figure showing the overall synthesis approach for semi-autonomous systems). Versatile and expressive specification languages such as linear temporal logic and signal temporal logic have been used in the approach. The project has also shown how to synthesize controllers for autonomous systems that interact in a natural manner with humans and human-controlled systems, such as autonomous vehicles interacting with pedestrians and human-driven vehicles (see attached image showing selected results for    autonomous driving). The results of this project have been demonstrated for the application of semi-autonomous driving, and technology transfer to industry has been initiated. The work was also presented in an invited talk at the Design Automation Conference.

(ii) Broader Impact: The project has been instrumental in training several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Undergraduate and junior graduate students have contributed to this project through capstone design projects offered in graduate and undergraduate courses taught by the PI at UC Berkeley. The PI has also disseminated results obtained in the project to a broader audience through tutorials and invited talks. Technology transfer    of the results to industry has been initiated through collaboration with several automotive companies.  

In summary, computational systems that interact with humans are growing in importance by the day in our society. The theory, techniques, and tools developed in this project provide steps to ensure their safe and correct operation, and to help train the next generation of scientists and engineers to design and operate these high-confidence interactive systems.
